abstract.p: Two top executives of Sirena Apparel Group who were fired for repeatedly resetting company computer's clock for 12 days to avoid closing books on first quarter of 1999 until revenue met analysts' forecasts are indicted on charges of securities fraud (S)

block.p: Deadlines are estimable things. For one, they are a universally respected excuse for brusqueness in dismissing distractions: ''Sorry, can't talk now. I'm on a deadline.'' For another, the visceral fear of missing a deadline motivates so powerfully that many people in high-pressure occupations say they have trouble accomplishing much without one. And where would Americans be without April 15?

Sometimes, though, an iron deadline turns counterproductive, as when labor negotiators have finally broken the logjam but have not quite tied up all the loose ends by midnight. The usual solution is to ''stop the clock'' until the deal is done.

Sometimes, though, an iron deadline turns counterproductive, as when labor negotiators have finally broken the logjam but have not quite tied up all the loose ends by midnight. The usual solution is to ''stop the clock'' until the deal is done.
Fine for union contracts, perhaps, but a company's books?

Two top executives of the Sirena Apparel Group, a California swimwear maker, appear to have tried the technique on their financial results, resetting the company computer's clock repeatedly for 12 days to avoid closing the books on the first quarter of 1999 until revenue had met analysts' forecasts, according to federal prosecutors. The maneuver fell apart within weeks, the executives were fired, and last week they were indicted on charges of securities fraud, according to a report in The Washington Post.
